author: Maribelle32
title: Donâ€™t waste money on roses
review:
Iâ€™m not impressed with this app.  I found the attractiveness level pretty low for the men I saw and the matches sent to me were all noâ€™s from me.  The â€œalgorithmâ€ is terrible (and Iâ€™m an attractive, educated woman).  I tried this app for a few months (both paid and free) bc I had heard it was the app to go on to find a relationship but the way the app works, I found very non conducive to maximizing matches. Notifying each time you send a â€œlikeâ€ made me less likely to send one if I was on the fence. I have gone on so many actual dates on Tinder and Bumble. With Hinge, I went on zero and had much fewer matches.  The conversations I had were lackluster and sometimes w men who were hours away.  I paid for 3 months to see all the likes I received at the same time and thinking Iâ€™d want to have more than 8 likes per day but I barely could find one per day.  (It was more like one per week).

Donâ€™t waste your money on buying extra roses.  The app makes you think you should buy them to match with the â€œstand outsâ€ but those people get recycled and show up again and again. Iâ€™m not even sure theyâ€™re all real profiles.  Itâ€™s a great marketing ploy but seems a bit like a scam. Thereâ€™s no way to know if the person received the rose, if youâ€™re outside their preferences. Also, the person gets a notification that a rose was sent to them from you and that itâ€™s extra special - so embarrassing (I only know this bc someone sent me one).  It wonâ€™t help you w getting more dates, believe me.  

Guess thereâ€™s an app for everyone but this is not the one for me. Hope others have better luck but learn from my mistake and donâ€™t waste your time or money on extra roses bc of the â€œstand outsâ€ list that you are sent.

title: Good overall, but â€œStandoutsâ€ is an awful feature
review:
At the basic level, the app is well built and functions well and I do really like to approach they take compared to other apps. However, the â€œStandoutsâ€ feature completely ruins the app my taking the most desirable women and putting them behind a paywall, essentially. You have to use a â€œroseâ€, which is like a super-like, instead of a normal like for this curated list of potential matches. The fact that you have to pay for additional roses beyond the one you get from time to time isnâ€™t even what bothers me, but it is the obligation to use a rose because it comes off as desperate and cheesy and Iâ€™ve NEVER had a match from a rose or super-like. It completely sabotages your chance with a girl to send a rose, so it makes these girls completely off limits. 
I actually had a girl from my â€œStandoutsâ€ like me organically, so I was able to match her and we had a couple of nice dates before it didnâ€™t work out, but that was the most exciting match with the best potential Iâ€™ve had from using this app and it never could have happened from my own initiation. author: dontworrybhappy
title: Designed to Delete Immediately ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ğŸ‘ğŸ¼ğŸ‘ğŸ¼
review: I started using Hinge about 2 months ago and I had really good results matching with women. The fact that you need to engage with people by text messaging to match, instead of just swiping leads to more interesting connections. After a few weeks I had 15 matches and 5 dates set up. So far so good. Then I came across a profile with 5 lackluster photos and a 6th photo that made the person look like a model. Maybe it was catfishing, but I liked the photo and told the person it was a really great shot and they should put it up higher. The women responded with a tirade about how men donâ€™t get to decide whatâ€™s a good photo or not, What the F**k, go to H**l, etc. I responded tongue and cheek and thought it was over. A day later I was banned. No warning, no temporary suspension, banned for life! It didnâ€™t matter than 15 other women had matched with me. One woman flagged me, and I was gone without even an explanation. Cancel culture at its best! Hinge hides behind the claim it is protecting women but in reality it is disrespecting men. It didnâ€™t even respect the women that had matched with me by giving them an explanation or a way to keep in touch. One woman that I had been texting with off the app, contacted me and asked why I unmatched with her. Hinge does some things right, but like many other hi-tech behemoths they think they own you, and they basically do. They can cancel you without notice or an explanation and you donâ€™t even get access to the the data and connections you made. Before you get too invested in this app, take a look at the board of directors. A bunch or corporate suits that donâ€™t look like they have been on a date since the 80s. Then do yourself a favor and delete the app before you waste your time. Who would have known thatâ€™s what they meant when they said the app was designed to be deleted.

author: Groupon?
title: Please read reviews before subscribing
review: While reluctantly, I'd say that this is my overall preference of the "apps" but it's been far less likable lately. The discover page has always been a mixed bag, some people aren't your type and some are, that's life. However, between standouts Ave the recent update, that no longer seems to be the case. The discover feed is filled with brand new accounts (which is fine, they've been the closest to the type of people I tend to match with) or accounts that are significantly different from any person I've ever matched with on the app. From incomplete profiles, to basic answer incompatibilities and an algorithm that clearly knows your preferences but ignores them behind a paywall. I purchased the premium model and I'm currently using it, I don't recommend. My best matches are in preferred, which is nice but I never see any of them in the feed and even with a premium account, you only get one way to match with you "preferred match" for free for a week. So, you'll see about 70 profiles that you really like in a week and you're only able to reach out to one, even with premium. It seems to me that the hinge algorithm has gotten better, as the preferred page has really good matches. However, that algorithm seems to go out the window for discover. For anyone who likes/liked this app, I'd recommend getting the free version. You'll save money and annoyance, you might even see more people that you like. It seems like I was served more people who are a good match before I paid, I'm assuming it's a way to make sure that free users see enough people that they like to think that it's worth it. It's not. You'll likely swipe through a sea of profiles are largely not what you're looking for only to be annoyed that you paid and still can't even send a basic like to your preferred matches. Save your money, use it for free and good luck finding love, or whatever else you're trying to find here

author: Thebestloollooool
title: They know exactly what they are doing and itâ€™s Terrible plz read
review:
the more I use hinge the more I realize their logarithms and their â€œpicksâ€ are very very messed up, very immature and most of all disgustingly hurtful. I truly wish I could post pictures to show you guys the evidence I have gathered to back all this up but as you use the app you will notice it as well. I find it odd that hinge has 2 categories of defining peopleâ€¦. There is the regular H  category at the bottom left where majority of people swipe on people and such and itâ€™s the main interaction place (in theory). Then they have the â€œStarâ€ category which is hinges EXCLUSIVE members that are supposed to be better matches for you! (In theory). But as you use the app, notice you probably swipe around 70/90 times in the H category before even swiping right once, and in the star category itâ€™s ALWAYS the woman or men that you truly find attractive in all areasâ€¦ the app after the first 30 people you like and try to match with understands â€œyour typeâ€ or the type of people you find attractive and kind and whoâ€™s personality is what youâ€™re looking for. Thatâ€™s the point of the app to find the GOOD matches for you. But what they donâ€™t tell you or want to admit is. Once they find out youâ€™re type and such they actually  throw the complete opposites types of people at you untill you have spent enough time and money on the app then the app rewards you with â€œCOMPATIBLE matchesâ€ what Iâ€™m trying to explain here is that Hinge is deliberately sending you the opposite types of people to you because they need more users spending time in the app then actully matching. Their target audience are desperate people who have had 0 luck still in their dating lives and have moved on from other apps like tinder And  okcupid and such etcâ€¦  Hinge knows exactly what they are doing and itâ€™s wasting our times and taking our money because there are enough desperate people to off set things. It actually makes me very sad to see how many opportunities we miss because we donâ€™t pay them 20$. Multiple people, friends, family etcâ€¦ can also confirm that 90% of hinges H matches for you are the opposite attractiveness, opposite personality type etc etcâ€¦. It shocks me how such an app can be so successful due to people in such desperation that they are will to go throw 70/90 people before swiping right on even one compared to paying 20$ for the â€œstarâ€ category.
I conclude this review with a sad disappointed head shake.

author: Kaskadiendevil

I had a very good conversation with someone that eventually led to us exchanging phone numbers. The red flag was that she unliked us in hinge immediately after we exchanged contact info and pursued to message me on WhatsApp (major red flag as WhatsApp is fully encrypted and they cannot read your messages) .Then it got really sketchy, it almost felt like the person on the other line was from a way foreign country or was a bot. 

The flow of the conversation went from smooth to being unable to comprehend basic sentences. Thatâ€™s how I knew it was a scam. 

The person had a very realistic profile , full of photos, believable information.

I since deleted the app as that was not the first impression I wanted. 

I probably could have approached this better,  I will stay off these apps for a while now.

Long story short, I needed to go home, and lost each other in the crowd while searching for my friend. I never got his number. 

For YEARS this guy was my â€œone that got away,â€ and I downloaded Hinge to try and find someone that enamored me as much as this guy from the party. I bragged about him to all my friends for YEARS, trying to find a mutual friend who knew him so I could reach out.

Within 2 days of having the app, I FOUND THE GUY! The funniest part wasâ€¦ he also had downloaded the app only a few days prior. We immediately reconnected and went on a date. He was my first and last Hinge date, and weâ€™ve now been happily together for the last two years. 

Long story short, try it out. You might just find the person youâ€™ve been searching for.

author: SJMReviews
title: Found my partner but customer service is terrible
review: I downloaded this app on a whim and was lucky to find a person I really liked. We have been dating now for several months and things look good. So I would definitely give this app 5 stars if that concluded the matter but thatâ€™s not where this ends. My partner and I decided to download our data from the app so we can keep the chat history as a reminder of our first conversations. He requested his on the app and received the data within a few days. I requested it and didnâ€™t receive anything. I re-requested it and again didnâ€™t receive anything. I emailed their support and they said I need to upload my photo ID to be able to receive my data. I am very uncomfortable with that. Also I didnâ€™t use my legal name on the app. My name is very unique and with just that info and a couple of other personal details I can be found a little too easily on Google. So for my safety I never use my legal name online (protect yourselves if you also have a unique name, there are some major crazies out there). Anyways I told them I was not comfortable with this and how come my partner was able to download his data? They said because he requested it on the app. I said I requested it on the app too several times, at this point I think Iâ€™ve requested it at least 10 times. They said that they would â€œescalate the matterâ€. I just emailed them again for an update and they are saying I need to upload my ID. First of all, weâ€™ve been through this several times already, it 100% feels like they do not fully read or grasp what I am saying on my email and second of all they said they were looking to correct this on 1/6/2022 and now I have to upload my ID? Why are we back to where we started? I am sad and disappointed because I really wanted my data. I sent my first email on 12/14/2021 and requested the data via the app starting in November. Still no resolution. I just reread my first email to them and I had told them from the beginning  that I had already requested my data via the app.

author: AdamStrickland
title: Hinge worked for me
review:
Iâ€™ll be honest, I had no faith in online dating or the prospect of meeting someone online that wasnâ€™t shady but Hinge was great for me. I downloaded the app in December 2021 and quickly had several matches of quality people who fit what I was looking for, but one of the first people I met ended up being amazing and we quickly developed a strong relationship. They were one of the â€œrecommended to meâ€ persons and we hit it off immediately. 

Just a few ideas on my end for Hinge, now that Iâ€™m done with the app and itâ€™s been deleted:

1- give a request for a deletion reason. Right now, when you delete the app, itâ€™s just deleted, but I feel like it should be asking why youâ€™re deleting so they can track the success of the app. Add me to the â€œdonâ€™t need it anymoreâ€ category. 

2- push users to take conversations offline. Right now, Hinge detects when a phone number is shared in chat and follows up asking if you met, but thatâ€™s it. I found a few conversations lingered in that â€œrelationship Q&Aâ€ phase but Hinge should push users to migrate off the app and move. Maybe after 5-10 messages send a prompt to each user to say â€œenjoying the conversation? Maybe you should meet!â€ to take away some anxiety some users may have in moving forward. 

3- entice users to send messages with their likes. This isnâ€™t Tinder; I had 10+ likes only with no comments. Those matches never pushed forward because the users werenâ€™t trying to engage me, so I didnâ€™t want to engage them. Bumble sends a â€œare your sureâ€ message when you try to send just a simple â€œheyâ€, Hinge should prevent likes only. 

Great app, thanks to the developers for this as itâ€™s been an awesome experience that I hope to never have to repeat!

author: ihatebadupdates
title: The best dating app out there but itâ€™s still awful
review:
Iâ€™ve tried them all folks, Hinge, Tinder, Clover, Eharmony, Match, The League, etc. This is the best and it used to be so great but now itâ€™s not... Letâ€™s ignore their new money grab scheme and just stick with the basics. 

Pros: Women message first. Lots of quick stats you can look at if people fill them out. Good and easy UI. Lots of users in many areas due to popularity.

Cons: The app doesnâ€™t force you to completely fill out the profile which leaves you looking at a lot of empty profiles. You can no longer use two free filters. Their customer support is non existent. If you donâ€™t use your account for awhile they seem to autodelete it but not really because you have to use a new email. The app uses a ton of data so it appears there are several networking issues. The app crashes consistently and logs you out. Even when I have good service, I have trouble sending and receiving messages. There are a ton of couples/polys on the app especially in my area and there needs to be a separate gender filter for that. And last but not least (actually itâ€™s the reason I updated this review): Iâ€™ve been banned from the app and they wonâ€™t tell me why and thereâ€™s no way to get unbanned from what I can tell. I have reached out to customer support but Iâ€™m not hopeful. Just for the record Iâ€™ve never done anything to violate their guidelines so I have no idea how this happened and itâ€™s definitely made me reconsider ever participating in online dating again.

author: mivkarlk88
title: These apps are toxic money pits with no soul.
review:
These apps are fundamentally toxic and are most likely rigged. Most people look at a picture and take 3-5 seconds to tell if someone is worth even initiating a conversation with. Both sides have to agree that the other looks to their standards. You are making an app that you use a picture to determine if someone LOOKS good. Both sides have to agree on looks of the other. If either side says no for any reason, they can no longer talk and itâ€™s a wasted connection. This is just the fundamental principle of this concept and is a reflection of a society and culture that only judges who they want to entertain based on LOOKS and nothing else. Any relationship that does get to happen will not be guaranteed to actually work as thereâ€™s more than someone than LOOKS. Society has made it so these and other apps are becoming the only means of social activity. No longer can you go out and physically see people and get to know them but thatâ€™s a whole other topic for other soapbox.

Now on to how the apps actually behave. You have to understand when someone swipes right on someone it doesnâ€™t need to tell the other party that they said yes to you. The app and the backend could just ignore it and tell you that you have no results. The app can also limit who sees your profile and what profiles you get to see. The app can hide your profile even if you are using their paid priority show me first mechanic. This here adds to a system that already puts the odds in the favor of the house. If Iâ€™m spending actual real life money on this app, I should be shown first to everyone when they open the app similar to lightning lane or fastpass. For the amount of money paid for premium subscription, they shouldnâ€™t be gatekeeping potential friends or otherwise and my profile should be shown to everyone and when me or someone swipes right, it should go through to the other person 100% of the time. A possible solution to that would be to show â€œpeople who you didnâ€™t like who liked youâ€ below people you didnâ€™t already make a decision on. You can still make money and not be rigged like a slot machine. I would like more transparency in the app and would like to see more metrics like how many people liked or disliked me. Another thing you can do is add â€œwhy do you like/dislike this personâ€ with 5 options so the other person can give constructive feedback or praise that they need to answer before going to the next person in line. The app and similar apps with similar to identical business models are toxic and are extremely harmful to a society of people with already low self confidence, anxiety and even sadly depression and social anxiety. If people are not liked on your apps, they might translate that to other social media and the real world and think they are worthless all because you want to make a buck and count beans. I know running an app and hiring people is not free but, like I said before you can still make money and let people actually connect to others. It shouldnâ€™t be rocket science to find a friend or otherwise on your apps especially when you pay a premium to use them.

author: ben dover72
title: Women messaging first rule is pointless.
review: The rule that women must message first makes no sense whatsoever. When two people match, there should be no further permission or confirmation needed in order to start chatting. We are adults, not children. If you do not want someone to message you, then do not swipe right on them. If you swiped right by accident and donâ€™t want to talk to them, then simply unmatch with them. 99% of the time I match with someone, they never even send that first message, so the chat expires. Can someone explain what the point of that is? I watch match after match expire and I am not even allowed to reach out and send a message to someone who, after all, showed interest in me. Since men cannot initiate conversation I think it is abusing the service for women to swipe right on men and never send them a message. Was it just the little ego boost they were after anyway? It makes for a very frustrating experience for men as their hands are tied and they have no way of reaching out. What a childish game. Most women simply say something like â€˜Hiâ€™ as a first message anyway, which is fine, but this essentially means that they still want you to start the conversation after all. I believe most women donâ€™t really want to message first, and if this is true then the rule is actually going against what most women want, making it even dumber. â€˜Women message firstâ€™ is a stupid and pointless extra step in the process. I cannot see how simply being the first to message after you match with someone empowers the woman in any way. Thatâ€™s not real empowerment, itâ€™s pointless virtue signaling by Bumble.

author: Chris Harding.
title: WARNING: Read Before Paying For Upgrade.
review:
Had several technical issues through the entirety of having the app.
(Messages, matches, etc) 
I had befriended one on Instagram who told me my messages was not going through to them on Bumble Business.

I decided to upgrade and get the life membership. (To save money long term)
And to be able to connect with more people.

They advertise and suggest these features are truly unlimited when itâ€™s not.

If you are on the free version they cap you on daily activity.

If you use the premium they see doing too much activity as spam. And can block you from the app  at any time without warning.

Due to all the technical issues I was having and people not getting my messages on the app.
I suggested people could reach out to me on Instagram or continue to speak here within the app.
(You can have your Instagram attached to your profile. Which would mean anyone could see your Instagram if they desired to.)
Which is why I ONLY shared a partnered app as an additional means of communication due to Bumbles technical issues.
I would of been more patient, however connections do expire if you do not message them promptly.

In all if I did it all over I would of stuck with the free version and only reach out to 5-10 people daily. And would of asked the other person their desired means of communication and not directly giving my own. 

Hope this review helps.

author: Louis R. Tursi
title: Thereâ€™s no harm in giving it a try.
review:
To the general public, here is what I have to say. The experience one may have on an app like Tinder is subjective. Itâ€™s different for everybody and can highly depend on where you are located, your profile, your intent, etc. Males beware: do not be surprised when the majority of women you ask to hook up with you decline. Females beware: do not be surprised when the majority of menâ€”or rather, boysâ€”ask you if youâ€™re down to hook up. Whatever gender you are, whichever gender you are seeking, and whatever your intention with an app like this is, do not set your expectations high. Download it, swipe based on your interests, close the app, and go about the rest of your day and just see what happens. If it goes well, great! If it doesnâ€™t, so what? Tinder is not the end-all-be-all, and that is my best advice.

Regarding the app itself though, as someone who has been using it on and off for a little over three years as of writing this, Iâ€™m surprised that itâ€™s still as incredibly buggy as it is given that it was released over a decade ago. For example, the notification badges on it get stuck on a random high number for no reason, despite me having opened all of my matches and reading all my messages. As of late, the information within the app does not even update. In other words, Iâ€™ll receive a new notification that Iâ€™ve gotten a new match or that someone has sent me a new message, and upon opening the app, nothing has changed. I have tried signing out and signing back in, deleting the app completely (followed by waiting a while) and reinstalling it, and Iâ€™ve even contacted support regarding all these issues and they were just about as helpful as my dogâ€™s sh*t.

To conclude, I personally love what this app has brought and contributed to my life. I donâ€™t know what my life would be like today without it, but I can guarantee it would not be the way it is now; far from it, in fact. Iâ€™ve been using it for nearly three years and have had a blast with it since I first signed up for it. With all that being said, just try it already. It really couldnâ€™t hurt; I honestly donâ€™t know what youâ€™re still waiting for. (Plus, youâ€™ve read this entire review for a reason, did you not?)

To the developers, all I have to say to you is... fix the functionality issues already. You update this app like once every two weeks claiming youâ€™ve "fixed bugs" (without any further explanation). Stop lying to make yourself look good, please and thank you.

The main issue with the app is that there are too many annoying and repetitive bugs that completely destroy the user experience. 

First off, why even have an option to â€œonly show people in this rangeâ€ if every other profile you show is 2000+ miles away from the range I set? I mean, I get it. The app runs out of users to show you after a while and is forced to recommend profiles outside the range. But then why not just say that the app has run out of profiles and leave it at that? My guess is that the devs are trying way too hard to waste peopleâ€™s time and keep them on the app as long as possible.

Second, literally every other swipe I get a notification that says â€œSuper like to increase your odds by 5x.â€ Now, I personally wouldnâ€™t care about the constant notification. But itâ€™s literally right above the profiles distance for you. Which is the number. one. consideration. when deciding on whether to swipe right or not. Again, this goes back to my initial theory that the devs are looking for ways to keep users on the app.

Often youâ€™ll see people that are thousands of miles away by mileage, or people that are nearby, but their â€œlive inâ€ city is thousands of miles away because theyâ€™re just visiting your area. Needs to be a setting to only show those people that are physically nearby and also live nearby, or where you can select it if you want to see visitors. Thereâ€™s no way to tell political leanings unless they put certain tags in their profile or put it in their bio. Thereâ€™s no way to know important things like if they have pets or drink/smoke unless they happened to answer those questions-theyâ€™re optional. Thereâ€™s no way to make it so you only see people that donâ€™t have pets or donâ€™t smoke or restrict out certain tags a person might add as their interest, for example â€œActivistâ€. To be a better app, these things need the focus, not the cutesy â€œVibesâ€ questions that donâ€™t have much meaning to whether theyâ€™re going to be a good partner or not. And having to â€œBoostâ€ in order to be seen by people you like is lame - it ought to just automatically put them front and center for them and tell you if they rejected you or not. Find a way to get the most active accounts paired waiting to match along with those who have already swiped right on you so you can match faster. I mean, if this app is based off the success of people being able to find matches I feel like it should be simpler and easier to find those matches. Then they proceed to tell me to sign up again, but thatâ€™s impossible because you have to use your phone number to sign up (you canâ€™t use a burn number) and my phone number is forever banned.

author: Sfubbkocn
title: Not good anymore
review: I've used tinder on and off for nearly eight years now and the quality of the app and interactions has gone off of a cliff. I've had Platinum for more than six months now and still hardly get any matches, even when using boosts, even during swipe surge, even when using boosts during swipe surge. Sometimes my profile will be shown at random times and I'll get 10 like within half an hour, but this doesn't happen too often and I'll only get a couple a day. The culture has also changed around it for the worse, many years ago it was super easy to have a bunch of matches that led to conversations that led to dates. Now almost none of the matches reply to my messages, and the ones that end up planning a date often cancel or don't show up to the date. I'm quite tired of feeling burnt out by this app and really don't see much of a future with it for myself or perhaps with other men that may be having the same experiences. It certainly isn't as good as it was in the 2013- 2017 era. In conclusion the best two words I could use to describe this app are depressing and overpriced.

author: **TaY**=o)
title: Male Users Leave Hinge In Droves As Algorithm Flops
review:
Hinge, at one point, was the â€˜diamond in the roughâ€™ dating app amongst a flurry of competitors. Its user interface encouraged a dialogue both in the forms of prompts and easy-to-engage photography seen on profiles.

For every 10 potential matches for men, maybe 4 or 5 would be of interest.

So what happened?

Like most apps nowadays, Hinge got to work on â€œimprovingâ€ its algorithm(s). The aim, obvious as it may seem, was to produce BETTER user experiences by matching users with seemingly similar traits, interests, and (purely subjective) â€œlevels of attractivenessâ€.

And now, for every 10 potential matches for men - *maybe* 1 is of interest (the experience reported by multiple male users).

What it did not take into consideration is the demographic breakdown of its users: roughly 65% are men while the remaining 35% are female (according to Hinge itself).

This disparity is also heightened by basic gender preferences, primarily the 80/20 principle, in that 20% of the men receive 80% of the attention of women (think of high school and how all of the girls wanted to date the boys on the football team).

In summary, the apps algorithm(s) have made matching a one-way street in which the women get plenty of potential matches with people of similar or higher attractiveness, whereas men do not.

So if youâ€™re a female searching for a male - youâ€™ll have no problem.

If youâ€™re a male searching for a female - youâ€™d have better odds of meeting a woman at an all-male prep academy.

(One was with someone I already knew and â€œbumped intoâ€ on the app). I used Bumble for a bit a couple years ago, and went on 3 dates within the first week.

review:
Shows no one you want and all those you donâ€™t. Is hinge a trash can for unattractive people?

Now days all the app shows are people Iâ€™d rank 3/10 or less. Itâ€™s as though by showing you all the undesirables, they think people are going to pay to unlock the less ugly peopleâ€¦.. really? The last month or so it has been purely unattractive girls, as in, the most unattractive that you without a doubt swipe left on immediately.  

Iâ€™m not gonna sugar coat it: 
This would make sense to improve statistics, as if all the regular/ hot girls are always getting matches and the uggos are not, the app wonâ€™t meet whatever goals the corporation have set for number of matches, therefore they push the uggos so they have the best chance of finding a match, and barely show the hotties seeing as they are likely to get many matches from just minimal exposure.

This algorithm would also fit this situation as I was getting too many matches so I have been dropped to the â€œshow leastâ€ or at-least â€œshow lessâ€ pool.

author: HamsterJuice
title: Arbitrary algorithm with overpriced premium "features"
review:
I've used this app two separate times a few years apart. The first time, finding matches was relatively easy and consistent and I met some really great people. I entered a relationship with one of them for a couple years and deleted the app.

A few months ago I redownloaded Bumble and Hinge. My experience with Bumble this time around has been pretty abysmal. The very first day there was an influx of likes, and in the weeks since I've received around 5 total. Compare this with Hinge, where likes are more direct than a simple right swipe, yet I receive them on a daily basis. I use the same photos on both apps; the only difference is the apps themselves.

That influx of likes you get your first day on Bumble seems very manipulative considering your profile will likely not receive that kind of attention ever again. They try to get you hooked with an initial burst of likes, and then they start pushing their absurdly priced premium features. It's embarrassingly transparent.

If you're serious about making quality connections, Bumble is unfortunately no longer the place to do it. Your time and energy are better spent elsewhere.

author: rantee
title: Elegant UI, unnecessary location usage
review:
This app is pleasant to use but its reliance on location permissions should be optional for two big reasons. Users should not be forced into this privacy-unfriendly design. Requiring *a* location is fine, but not my precise location. Which relates to reason 2 -

The radius-based search is often meaningless and hides many relevant matches - there are many places 20 miles away from my home that I can get to faster than others that are 10 miles away. If I could manually enter or change my zip code, for example, I could find much more geographically-relevant matches.

Finally, the subscriptions are too pricey.

author: Simanonok
title: Improved from before
review:
The developer had made his own Bumble obsolete on older iPhones, but now has apparently fixed that problem so Iâ€™m back to testing if itâ€™s really usable. 

Two major problems I see are 

1) the use of meaningless hieroglyphic icons that seem to randomly switch around on every page makes navigation very tedious and difficult; WHEN will developers learn to use text menus that we can just look at to see what theyâ€™re for, instead of having to experiment by clicking on every one to see if they do something useful or are what weâ€™re looking for?  A single drop down text menu in the upper left corner where menus belong would be a massive improvement in usability, instead of scattering meaningless hieroglyphs randomly around the screen. 

2) poor contrast of light yellow-orangey text on white backgrounds in Setup areas makes certain operations slow and difficult. Not as bad as the use of meaningless icons, but still unnecessary. Suspect the developer isnâ€™t using naive testers on a variety of devices like he should, but instead is probably developing on a Mac with a high contrast screen where his light-on-light text is discernible and where the use of meaningless hieroglyphics for navigation has long been standard practiceâ€”and the reason that I and many others loathe Apple products.

Or Iâ€™ll waste a super swipe because I couldnâ€™t undo it in time. Itâ€™s really easy to make a mistake from the beeline view where profiles are shown two per row, because you try to swipe the person on the left and it selects the person on the right. (Though if this were fixed, the two per row is nice.) 

My biggest issue â€” my beeline my filters donâ€™t work at all, so Iâ€™m stuck going thru matches that are way outside of my distance parameters in order to review the people who are local. 

Not worth the cost of premium AT ALL when these feature's donâ€™t work.

Iâ€™m old enough to know what I want and what I donâ€™t want, and itâ€™s painfully obvious that people donâ€™t read profiles, so why arenâ€™t the preference settings more robust?
Iâ€™m not talking about the shallow things like height or whatever, but whether my profile gets show to people who live out of town and need a tour guide because they havenâ€™t heard of Rick Steves, or are looking for a unicorn to throuple with. I am interested in neither of those things, thank you. It seems like it would be highly useful to partition what information you share with others given the Bizz and BFF settings, and to have more control over that â€”Iâ€™m not going to talk about the same things with each of those groups on a first or second meeting and want to present myself accordingly.

title: Gender settings are nice, but a bit weird.

But what really gets me here, is the way they handle gender identity and how they categorize it. Iâ€™m a trans male, whoâ€™s interested in women, and Iâ€™ve had no problems in my past with dating women. But if I change my gender identity to â€œtrans manâ€ on this app and set my preference as â€œwomenâ€ my feed is changed to nothing but other women who are interested in women, or people looking for â€œpolyâ€ relationships. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m quite what lesbians are looking for bumble? But once I set my gender back to â€œmaleâ€ Iâ€™m brought back to women who are interested in men. So I have no choice but to just put â€œmaleâ€ and then that Iâ€™m â€œtransâ€ in my bio. So maybe something needs to be changed about that? Why should I feel that Iâ€™m less of a man on this app? I get that you try and pair â€œlgbtq+â€ with others in that same category, but make it make sense. If I say Iâ€™m â€œstraightâ€ I should only be seeing what my preference is. If others choose to not like me because Iâ€™m trans, let them make that decision.

This smaller number of swipes is sold under the illusion of â€œthoughtful swiping,â€ but if the company actually cared about â€œthoughtful swipingâ€ then they wouldnâ€™t offer unlimited swiping like they do in their paid version in the first place. They also took away the free back track feature that lets you bring back profiles you accidentally swiped left on, and took away the ability to bring back one expired match every 24 hours. author: Pinkie B
title: BFF has gender issues
review:
I'm a female who prefers male friends. I list myself as "genderqueer" because I think it best represents my personality, and because doing so allows me to choose how I want to present. 

Bumble only allows me to show my profile to people who want to match with men OR who want women, but not either or both at once. This is a major flaw in gender representation if ultimately you are forced into the binary box. 

According to this app gender really is just a label, but doesn't have any real effect on your relationships. I think they're massively missing the point. 

Oh, and their prices are outrageous.

author: WesleyG92
title: Bumble BFF is Homophobic
review:
Bumble BFF inherently recognizes that people need to make friends, new friends. This is especially crucial when for example you move or enter a period of new growth. And BFF inherently recognizes that people sometimes are solely looking for friends where sex can never be an option and harassment is a nonstarter, hence it limits matches only to the same gender. That only works for heterosexual people, and there is no way to change that setting. Cis-identifying queer people have no way of seeking platonic friendships safe from the risk of harassment or sexual pressure. And the utilization of the binary completely removes choice and sense of belonging for trans and non-binary folx for whom harassment and sexual pressure are never off the table anyways.

In short, why is the platonic side of this app geared first and foremost with cis-hets in mind, with virtually no liberty for queer people? Do we not deserve friends of our own choosing? Are we inherently incapable of making lasting and deep friendships with others of different gender identities?? Bumble BFF answers the latter two questions with a resounding YES. Shameful.

First of all, it seems bizarre that bumble isnâ€™t regulating or tracking whether profiles belong to individuals or couples, and second, if theyâ€™re allowing couples to have profiles, then they should at least also give users the option to filter them out and only see individuals if they so choose.

The whole experience just feels icky to me because Iâ€™m looking for someone to date monogamously, and I donâ€™t like thinking that these straight men are just reviewing my profile wondering if Iâ€™ll be the one to help him fulfill his gross fantasy of a threesome with a lesbian who **maybe he can turn!**

Then I realized the $8 a week was for very limited things and then saw it was $33 a month to see who saw your profile! Please give us the ads I would much rather that than having to pay such a ridiculous amount. Or please bring back the 3 free backtrack for crappy situations like the accidental left swipe.
